citation.article-title: Further determination of DNA relatedness between serogroups and serovars in the family Leptospiraceae with a proposal for Leptospira alexanderi sp. nov. and four new Leptospira genomospecies.

p.s: Description of Leptospira alexanderi sp. nov.
Leptospira alexanderi (a.lex.an'der.i. N.L. gen. n. alexanderi to honour Aaron D. Alexander, an American microbiologist who has devoted more than 40 years to the study of leptospires)

The first leptospiral DNA hybridization studies that were conducted in Professor Alexander's laboratory in 1969 and 1974 (Haapala et al., 1969; Brendle et al., 1974) inspired the study of Yasuda et al. (1987) and the present study.
Cells are Gram-negative, flexible and helical.
Motile by means of two flagella (axial fibriles).
NaCl is not required for growth.
Growth is inhibited by 8-azaguanine (225 μg ml-1) and 2,6-diaminopurine (10 μg ml-1).
Growth in the presence of copper sulfate (100 p.p.m.) and production of lipase are variable.
It contains serovars from serogroup Manhao (serovar lushui and manhao 3), Hebdomadis (serovar manzhuang and nanding), Javanica (serovar mengla) and Mini (serovar yunnan).
All strains isolated to date are from China.
The type strain, L 60T (=ATCC 700520T; serovar manhao 3) was isolated in China from an unknown source.
DNA relatedness among the strains in the species and their relatedness to other leptospires are shown in Tables 2 and 3.
